block.p: Microsoft Begins Appealing Decision in Antitrust Case Microsoft filed part of its appeal of its antitrust case, asserting that the trial judge committed ''an array of serious substantive and procedural errors that infected virtually every aspect of the proceedings.''

Microsoft filed the document with the Court of Appeals, while the Justice Department filed a motion to take the case directly to the Supreme Court. The judges of the appeals court issued an order saying the entire court, minus three judges who recused themselves, would hear the case ''in view of its exceptional importance.'' But if the Supreme Court eventually decides to take the direct appeal, the appeals court will have to stand down. Shares of Microsoft rose $1, to $67.875. [Page A1.]

Managed Care Not in the Clear Yet The Supreme Court blasted a hole in the courtroom assault on managed care this week, pleasing Wall Street, but outside experts and lawyers on both sides in dozens of lawsuits insisted that there were still plenty of issues left to fight over. Market Place. [C13.]

Global Crossing and Equant in Talks Global Crossing, the upstart communications carrier, has recently entered discussions to acquire Equant, which controls perhaps the world's most geographically extensive communications network, people close to the talks said. Equant remains in merger talks with France Telecom. [C2.]

Dow, Nasdaq and S.& P. Increase Stocks broke out of a slump on investors' optimism over the state of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 57.63 points, to 10,621.84. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 23.44 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,469.44, and the Nasdaq composite index was up 83.15 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,851.06. [C16.]

Company to Transmit Films Online Sightsound.com, a digital video and music distribution company, plans to announce today that it will make its movies available as encrypted files on the Internet using the controversial Gnutella software. [C16.]

J. P. Morgan Finds Itself Unplugged J. P. Morgan found itself without a Web site or an e-mail connection to the outside world because it had failed to renew the registration of www.jpmorgan.com, the domain name that serves as its Web address. [C17.]

Fifth Third: Not Your Typical Bank Employees of the Fifth Third Bancorp often spend their free time trolling for new accounts for their banks. Why? Bonuses, awards and other incentives. Monthly performance postings. And frequent pep talks by the brass. ''This isn't a social-service agency,'' says the chairman, George A. Schaefer, a West Point graduate and Vietnam veteran. ''It's capitalism.'' Management. [C11.]

An Executive's Football Lessons Michael Wright, how do you run Supervalu, the nation's biggest grocery wholesaler? ''It's a little like football practice: you're banging your head and banging your head; if you stopped and thought about it, you might not do it. But football also taught me not to take myself too seriously. Here, everybody from top management to the cleaning staff calls me Mike. We work hard at fighting egos.'' The Boss. [C11.]

Progress Seen in Privacy Standards The Federal Trade Commission and Internet advertisers said they had made progress negotiating a set of voluntary privacy standards for the companies to follow when building profiles of Web surfers. But the commission was not ready to say whether such an agreement would go far enough to eliminate the need for federal legislation. Advertising. [C10.]
